column1: Bouar is a market town in the western Central African Republic
column2: lying on the main road from Bangui (437 km) to the frontier with Cameroon (210 km). The city is the capital of Nana-Mambéré prefecture
column5: while the whole sous-préfecture has a population of 96
column6: 595 (2003 census). Bouar lies on a plateau almost 1000m above sea level and is known as the site of Camp Leclerc

column1: About seventy groups of megaliths lie in the town and to its north and east.  The Bouar Megaliths
column2: dating back to the very late Neolithic Era (c. 3500–2700 BC) were added to the UNESCO World Heritage Tentative List on April 11

column1: Bouar was ceded by France to Germany under the terms of the 1912 Morocco-Congo Treaty
column2: becoming part of the German colony of Neukamerun until it was reconquered by the French during World War I. The town was occupied and burned down in the late 1920s by Gbaya rebels during the Kongo-Wara rebellion.

column1: As of February 2014 the town and region around Bouar were experiencing ethnic cleansing
column2: principally against Muslim civilians. A French journalist
column4: was also killed and her body found in the car of Anti-balaka troops in the Bouar region in May

column1: Köppen-Geiger climate classification system classifies its climate as tropical wet and dry (Aw).
